habitat_description:
Historically, populations of the blunt-nosed leopard lizard were found in the San Joaquin Valley and surrounding foothills of southern California. Its range extended from Stanislaus County to northern Santa Barbara and Ventura Counties, below 800 meters in elevation (Jennings 1995; USFWS 1998). The current range is comprised of scattered parcels of undeveloped land on the San Joaquin Valley and the foothills of the Coast Range (USFWS 1998).

More specifically, the populations that occur in the northern part of the San Joaquin Valley are found in the Firebaugh and Madera Essential Habitat Areas (Williams 1990), also the Ciervo, Tumey, and Panoche Hills, Anticline Ridge, Pleasant Valley, Lone Tree, Sandy Mush Road, Whitesbridge, Horse Pasture, and the Kettleman Hills Essential Habitat Areas.

The southern San Joaquin Valley harbors populations of this species in Pixley National wildlife Refuge, Liberty Farm, Allensworth, Antelope Plain, Kern National Wildlife Refuge, Elk Hills, Buttonwillow, and Tupman Essential Habitat Areas. Also occur on the Carrizo and Elkhorn Plains; western Kern County around Maricopa, McKittrick, and Taft; base of Tehachapi Mountains on Tejon Ranch; and west of the California Aqueduct on the Tejon and San Emizidio Ranches (USFWS 1998). This species can be found in the grassland habitat of Merced and Madera Counties; Obispo County and Santa Barbara County (Jones and Lovich 2009).

The habitat of these localities of the San Joaquin Valley is described to be made up of grasslands, herbaceous zones, playas, salt flats, shrubland, and chaparral. This lizard can be found on low foothills, large washes, canyon floors, arroyos, and semi-arid grasslands (Natureserve.org).

Favors habitats comprised of clump grass, saltbrush grassland; washes with brush in grassland; and alkali flats. It is considered rare in dense vegetation or tall grass. Also found in non-native grasslands and ephedra shrub habitat
